elements.html:
Our Mission

The North Carolina State Collaborative for Children, Youth, and Families, through a System of Care framework, provides a forum for collaboration, advocacy and action among families, public and private child and family serving agencies and community partners to improve outcomes for all children, youth and families.

Our Vision

Children, youth and families are healthy, safe and successful at home, in school and in their communities.

What is the State Collaborative for Children, Youth, and Families?

The State Collaborative: 

  • Provides a forum for the discussion of issues regarding how agencies, youth, and families can work together to produce better outcomes for children, youth and families.
  • Develops recommendations regarding the coordination of services, funding, training and local reporting requirements to eliminate duplication and make the system more consumer friendly.
  • Includes representatives of a range of state and local agencies, youth, families, and advocates.
  • Provides support for local Collaboratives and Child and Family Teams.

Mission of Training Committee

To design and deliver interagency/family and youth driven practice through training, conferences, Learning Institutes and other forums that promote best practices.

  • CHILD AND FAMILY TEAMS: FROM THE FAMILY’S PERSPECTIVE-This year we have provided a train the trainer for over thirty Provider/ Family/Youth teams that will train this curriculum all over North Carolina.
  • We STRIVE TO develop collaboration among providers, families and youth.

Cultural Competencies / Health Disparities

Mission

Healthy People 2020 defines a health disparity as a:

“particular type of health difference that is closely linked with social, economic, and/or environmental disadvantage. Health disparities adversely affect groups of people who have systematically experienced greater obstacles to health based on their racial or ethnic group; religion; socioeconomic status; gender; age; mental health; cognitive, sensory, or physical disability; sexual orientation or gender identity; geographic location; or other characteristics historically linked to discrimination or exclusion.” Significant behavioral health disparities persist in diverse communities across the United States, including but not limited to: racial and ethnic groups; low SES populations; lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning (LGBTQ) populations; and transition-age youth.

elements.html:
Top Accomplishments & Advocacy Efforts

  • Partnership with state leaders
    • Designed the local System of Care (SOC) Learning Institutes
    • Supported Raise the Age initiative; and school based mental health initiative with legislators and decision makers
    • Connecting leaders with family and youth voice
    • Work in partnership to increase strategies for family partners
  • Development and roll out of orientation video and new member packets
  • Governance committee for the SOC Expansion grant
  • Partnered with NC Child, NCFU, SAYSO and Youth M.O.V.E. to present informational forum about new child welfare legislation.
  • Development and follow through on strategic plan
  • Revision, roll out and technical assistance of the Child & Family Team 1 (CFT 1) training
    • Supporting twenty-eight agency staff and family partner teams across the state

question3
elements.title: The North Carolina Collaborative for Children, Youth and Families is:
choices: An equal forum for agency staff, family and youth leaders
A group run by cross system state leaders
A group that wants to maintain the status quo in North Carolina
An organization that believes parents need parenting classes.
elements.correctAnswer: An equal forum for agency staff, family and youth leaders

elements.name: question4
elements.title: The North Carolina Collaborative for Children, Youth and Families:
choices: Has nothing to do with local collaborative
Believes in the inclusion of families and youth in every aspect of service delivery and policy
Has to meet two times a month because of policy.
elements.correctAnswer: Believes in the inclusion of families and youth in every aspect of service delivery and policy
